case_vignette: A 60-year-old woman presents with changes in her left breast that started 1 month ago. The patient states that she noticed that an area of her left breast felt thicker than before, and has not improved. She came to get it checked out because her best friend was just diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma. The past medical history is significant for Hashimoto’s thyroiditis, well-managed medically with levothyroxine. The patient has a 30-pack-year smoking history, but she quit over 15 years ago. The menarche occurred at age 11, and the menopause was at age 53. She does not have any children and has never been sexually active. Her last screening mammogram 10 months ago was normal. The family history is significant for her mother dying from a myocardial infarction (MI) at age 68, her sister dying from metastatic breast cancer at age 55, and for colon cancer in her paternal grandfather. The review of systems is notable for unintentional weight loss of 3.6 kg (8 lb) in the past month. The vital signs include: temperature 37.0℃ (98.6℉), blood pressure 110/70 mm Hg, pulse 72/min, respiratory rate 15/min, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. The physical examination is significant only for a minimally palpable mass with irregular, poorly defined margins in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. The mass is rubbery and movable. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy noted.
question: Which  characteristics is associated with this patient’s most likely type of breast cancer in comparison to her friend’s diagnosis?

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I noticed that an area of my left breast felt thicker than before and it hasn't improved.

Great, thank you for sharing that with me. Can you tell me more about the thickening you're experiencing in your left breast? How long have you noticed this change, and has it been constant or does it come and go?
I've been feeling this thickening in my left breast for about a month now, and it's been constant.

Thank you for letting me know. Have you noticed any other changes in your breast, such as a change in size, shape, or color? And have you had any recent changes in your menstrual cycle or sexual activity?
I haven't noticed any changes in size, shape, or color, and I've been through menopause and am not sexually active.

Great, thank you for clarifying that. Based on what you've told me, I would like to ask you a few more questions to help narrow down the possible causes of the thickening in your left breast.

Can you tell me if you have a family history of breast cancer or any other cancers? And have you noticed any other symptoms such as a lump, nipple discharge, or changes in the skin of your breast?
My sister died from metastatic breast cancer, and my paternal grandfather had colon cancer. Also, I can feel a lump in my left breast, but there's no nipple discharge or changes in the skin.

Thank you for sharing that information. Based on what you've told me, I would like to recommend that you schedule an appointment with a breast specialist or a general surgeon for further evaluation. The lump in your left breast could be a sign of a benign or malignant condition, and it's important to have it evaluated by a medical professional.

The breast specialist or surgeon will perform a thorough examination and may recommend additional tests such as a mammogram, ultrasound, or biopsy to determine the cause of the lump. If the lump is found to be cancerous, early detection and treatment can improve the chances of successful treatment and survival.

Please make sure to follow up with the recommended medical professional for further evaluation and treatment.

Final Diagnosis: Benign or malignant breast lump.

I've noticed an area in my left breast that feels thicker than it used to, and it hasn't gotten better.

I went through menopause when I was 53 and I've not had any children or been sexually active.

Great, thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms and medical history, I would like to recommend a few tests to help us further evaluate the cause of the lump in your breast.

Can you tell me, have you had any previous breast surgeries or procedures? And do you have any family history of breast cancer or other cancers?
I haven't had any breast surgeries or procedures, but my sister died from metastatic breast cancer at age 55 and my paternal grandfather had colon cancer.

Thank you for sharing that information. Based on your family history, it is possible that the lump in your breast could be related to inherited genetic mutations that increase the risk of breast and ovarian cancer.

I would like to refer you to a genetic counselor for further evaluation and testing. This will help us determine if you have a higher risk of developing breast or ovarian cancer, and if there are any steps you can take to reduce your risk.

In the meantime, I would like you to have a mammogram of your breast to rule out any other possible causes of the lump. Can you schedule a mammogram with your primary care physician or a radiology clinic?

My last screening mammogram was 10 months ago and it was normal, but I'll schedule another one as you've suggested.

It's important to rule out any potential causes of the lump, such as a cyst or a benign tumor, before we consider the possibility of cancer.

I would like to refer you to a breast imaging specialist for further evaluation. They will perform a diagnostic mammogram and possibly an ultrasound to better evaluate the lump and determine the next steps for your care.

In the meantime, I would like you to have a clinical breast examination (CBE) by your primary care physician or a breast health specialist. This will help us assess the size, shape, and consistency of the lump, as well as any other abnormalities in your breast tissue.

In the meantime, it's important to continue with regular breast self-exams and clinical breast exams by a healthcare provider to help detect any changes in your breasts early on, when they are most treatable.
